45:59 Caption: Well, a decent first half here. It's certainly not boring, but not the best match either. Real Madrid dominated the opening period and easily created the most chances. The home team are playing possession football, while the away team look to find a weakness in the opposition's defence mainly with their rapid counter-attacks.

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
In a highly anticipated La Liga clash, Real Madrid took on Granada at the Santiago Bernabéu Stadium. The game concluded with a narrow 1-0 victory for Real Madrid, thanks to a solitary goal from Karim Benzema. Despite the seemingly modest scoreline, the match was rich in action, with Real Madrid showcasing their dominance while Granada put up valiant resistance. Here's a detailed description of the match proceedings.

The game commenced with Real Madrid taking the initial kick-off. The first few minutes were characterized by a series of throw-ins and stoppages as both teams looked to find their rhythm. Early on, Real Madrid appeared the more assertive side, pressing forward and putting pressure on Granada's defense.

At the 3rd minute, a foul by Granada resulted in an indirect free-kick for Real Madrid. Toni Kroos floated the ball into the box, and although it didn't result in a direct goal-scoring opportunity, it signaled Real Madrid's intent to control the game. Around the 6th minute, Real Madrid were caught offside, handing possession back to Granada through an indirect free-kick.

Granada managed the first shot off target at around the 7th minute, a signal that they were willing to take chances despite being largely on the defensive. This was quickly followed by a string of throw-ins for both teams, reflecting a somewhat scrappy phase of the match.

As the game progressed, Real Madrid’s Luka Modric earned a corner at the 9th minute, but Granada's defense remained resolute, clearing the danger. Real Madrid continued to dominate possession, attempting to break down the Granada defense through intricate passing and positioning.

One of Real Madrid's most significant early chances came around the 11th minute when a corner taken short by Toni Kroos found Karim Benzema, who sent a cross into the box. Yet, Granada's defense, well-organized as ever, managed to clear the ball to safety. This sequence reflected the ongoing battle: Real Madrid's persistent attacking against Granada's disciplined defense.

In one of their more coordinated moves shortly after, Isco attempted a long-range shot from outside the box. However, Granada's goalkeeper, Andres Fernandez, was alert, making a comfortable save. This set the tone for Fernandez's performance, as he would continue to frustrate Real Madrid's attackers throughout the game.

Around the 15th minute, Cristiano Biraghi from Granada committed a rough foul, resulting in an indirect free-kick for Real Madrid. Although Real Madrid positioned themselves for a shot, Granada's defense absorbed the pressure well. A few moments later, another free-kick on the Real Madrid side saw Isco firing towards goal, only to be denied once again by Fernandez.

Granada had their moments too, particularly around the 19th minute when Youseff El Arabi found himself offside, halting what could have been a promising attack. Nonetheless, Real Madrid reclaimed control and continued to press forward. 

Midway through the first half, Real Madrid's Isco and Modric combined well, earning a series of corners and free-kicks following fouls by Granada. Despite Real Madrid's dominance and numerous shots on target, they were continuously thwarted by Fernandez, who put on an impressive display of goalkeeping.

Around the 34th minute, Edgar Mendez of Granada was booked for a harsh challenge, the first yellow card of the match. This moment hinted at Granada’s increasing physicality as they tried to contain Real Madrid's relentless offense.

Towards the end of the first half, Real Madrid had a few more near-misses, notably from Karim Benzema and Isco, who managed only to put their shots narrowly off target. Granada, on the other hand, had an opportunity through Miguel Lopes, whose strike flew just over the crossbar.

The first half ended with Real Madrid firmly in control, having dominated possession and created more chances. However, Granada's defense held strong, keeping the scoreline at 0-0. The half-time whistle was a welcome break for Granada, who had spent much of the half under siege.

The second half began with Granada taking the kick-off. Real Madrid swiftly resumed their assault on Granada’s goal. Cristiano Ronaldo, renowned for his spectacular solo runs, attempted a long-range effort within the first minute, but Fernandez made another comfortable save.

Real Madrid continued to press, and within minutes Karim Benzema's efforts nearly paid off. This time, it was a lofted pass from Isco that reached Benzema, who expertly directed a header past Fernandez in the 9th minute. The Santiago Bernabéu erupted as Real Madrid took a deserved 1-0 lead.

Granada, however, did not fold. They tried to mount a response, but Real Madrid's defense, led by the likes of Sergio Ramos and Raphael Varane, was quick to snuff out any danger. Around the 16th minute, Granada substituted Isaac Success for Robert Ibanez, an attempt to inject fresh legs into their attack.

Rafael Benitez, the Real Madrid coach, also made his first substitution around the same time, bringing on Mateo Kovacic for Toni Kroos. This substitution indicated Benitez's desire to maintain midfield control while adding fresh energy to Real Madrid's gameplay.

Real Madrid continued their dominance, with Cristiano Ronaldo once again testing Fernandez from a long-range effort. Granada’s defense remained resilient but strained under continuous pressure.

Granada’s best opportunity came just past the hour mark when Youssef El Arabi, having received a defense-splitting pass, unleashed a strike from a promising distance. Keylor Navas, Real Madrid's goalkeeper, made a fantastic save to deny what would have been the equalizer.

Real Madrid's substitutions continued as Rafael Benitez introduced Denis Cheryshev for Karim Benzema around the 32nd minute, followed shortly by Casemiro replacing Isco. These fresh players were part of Benitez’s strategy to maintain defensive solidity while continuing to press for a second goal.

Granada's persistence saw them earn several free-kicks and corners, but they struggled to convert these into clear opportunities. In the 44th minute, they got a direct free-kick in a promising position, but Javier Marquez's effort was blocked by the defensive wall.

As the game ticked towards its conclusion, Real Madrid aimed to manage possession and run down the clock. They showcased great ball retention, frustrating Granada’s attempts to win back possession. Despite four added minutes, Granada could not break through Real Madrid’s organized defense.

The match ended 1-0, with Real Madrid claiming all three points. While the scoreline indicates a close contest, in reality, Real Madrid controlled large portions of the match. Their offensive prowess was evident through the numerous shots on target and the impressive interplay among midfielders and forwards.

Granada’s Andres Fernandez undoubtedly emerged as one of the standout performers, making several crucial saves to keep his team in the game. Despite the loss, Granada’s defense showcased resilience and determination, attributes that will serve them well throughout the rest of the season.

Overall, the game highlighted Real Madrid's tactical discipline, attacking flair, and ability to control the game—from possession play to defensive organization. Karim Benzema's crucial header was a testament to Real Madrid's persistence and quality in critical moments. Granada walked away without any points but with the recognition that their defensive fortitude had kept the scoreline respectable against one of the world's premier football clubs.
